senses.definition: a small area of land in a town that a person can rent in order to grow fruit and vegetables on it
an amount of something that somebody is given or allowed to have; the process of giving something to somebody

the allotment of shares to company employees

senses.definition: a shelter in a garden for people to sit under, made by growing climbing plants over a frame
a tool with a wooden handle and a heavy metal blade, used for cutting up wood, cutting down trees, etc.

examples.x: to chop a tree down with an axe

senses.definition: if somebody gets the axe, they lose their job; if an institution or a project gets the axe, it is closed or stopped, usually because of a lack of money the axe

examples.x: Up to 300 workers are facing the axe at a struggling Merseyside firm.
Patients are delighted their local hospital has been saved from the axe.
Protesters, anxious over the spending cuts, urged councillors to think again before wielding the axe.

senses.definition: the whole area behind and belonging to a house, including an area of grass and the garden

examples.x: He grew vegetables in his backyard.
a backyard barbecue

senses.definition: an area with a hard surface behind a house, often surrounded by a wall

examples.x: They lived in a little terraced house with a backyard behind it and a tiny garden in front.

senses.definition: a metal frame for cooking food on over an open fire outdoors

examples.x: I put another steak on the barbecue.
a barbecue sausage (= cooked in this way)

senses.definition: an outdoor meal or party when food is cooked in this way

examples.x: Let's have a barbecue!

senses.definition: a metal frame for cooking food on over an open fire outdoors
an outdoor meal or party when food is cooked in this way
a long seat for two or more people, usually made of wood

examples.x: a park bench

senses.definition: a judge in court or the seat where he/she sits; the position of being a judge or magistrate

examples.x: His lawyer turned to address the bench.

senses.definition: (in the British parliament) a seat where a particular group of politicians sit

examples.x: There was cheering from the Opposition benches.

senses.definition: the seats where players sit when they are not playing in the game

He's sick of spending every game on the bench.

senses.definition: a long heavy table used for doing practical jobs, working with tools, etc.

examples.x: a carpenter’s bench

senses.definition: a wooden platform in a garden on which people put food for birds
the line that divides two countries or areas; the land near this line border

border crossings

a border town/village/county
a border region/area

senses.definition: a long narrow piece around the edge of something such as a picture or a piece of cloth

examples.x: a pillowcase with a lace border

senses.definition: a long narrow area of soil which is planted with flowers, along the edge of the grass

these stems used as a material for making furniture, etc.

senses.definition: a piece of cane or a thin stick, used to help somebody to walk

senses.definition: a structure made of metal bars joined together for children to climb and play on
a piece of thin rope or wire, attached to posts, that you hang clothes on to dry outside after you have washed them

wood used to build a floor (called a deck) in the garden next to or near a house

examples.x: They drank a pot of coffee.

senses.definition: a bowl, etc. that is made by a potter

examples.x: The newly made pots are glazed when they are completely dry.

senses.definition: the total amount of money that is bet in a card game
all the money given by a group of people in order to do something together, for example to buy food, or available for a particular purpose
cannabis (= a drug (illegal in many countries) made from the dried leaves and flowers of the hemp plant, which gives the person smoking it a feeling of being relaxed)

examples.x: pot smoking

senses.definition: a shot that somebody fires without aiming carefully

examples.x: He took a pot at the neighbour's cat with his air rifle.

senses.definition: the act of hitting a ball into one of the pockets around the edge of the table
a pot belly (= a large stomach that sticks out)
to put a plant into a flowerpot filled with soil
to hit a ball into one of the pockets (= holes at the corners and edges of the table)

examples.x: He potted the black to take a 7–3 lead.

senses.definition: to kill an animal or a bird by shooting it
a small building where seeds and young plants are grown in pots before they are planted outside
to cut off some of the branches from a tree, bush, etc. so that it will grow better and stronger

examples.x: When should you prune apple trees?
He pruned the longer branches off the tree.
The hedge needs pruning back.

senses.definition: to make something smaller by removing parts; to cut out parts of something

examples.x: Staff numbers have been pruned back to 175.
The railway companies have pruned their timetables (= there are fewer trains).
Prune out any unnecessary details.
Their budgets have been drastically pruned.

senses.definition: a large barrel for collecting rain as it flows off a roof
an area in a garden that is higher than the ground around it and is usually surrounded by a frame made of wood or stone

examples.x: Vegetables and herbs were grown in a raised bed.

senses.definition: a garden tool with a long handle and a row of metal points at the end, used for gathering fallen leaves and making soil smooth
a man, especially a rich and fashionable one, who was thought to have low moral standards, for example because he drank or gambled a lot or had sex with a lot of women
the amount by which something, especially the stage in a theatre, slopes
to pull a rake over a surface in order to make it level or to remove something

examples.x: The leaves had been raked into a pile.
She raked a comb through her hair.
First rake the soil smooth.

senses.definition: to point a camera, light, gun, etc. at somebody/something and move it slowly from one side to the other

examples.x: They raked the streets with machine-gun fire.
Searchlights raked the grounds.

senses.definition: to search a place carefully for something

examples.x: She raked around in her bag for her keys.

senses.definition: to scratch the surface of something with a sharp object, especially your nails
a garden on the flat roof of a building

examples.x: The hotel has a charming roof garden.

senses.definition: a tool with a long handle and a slightly curved blade (= sharp metal cutting edge), held in two hands and used for cutting long grass, etc.
a garden tool like a pair of strong scissors, used for cutting plant stems and small branches

examples.x: a pair of secateurs

senses.definition: the small hard part produced by a plant, from which a new plant can grow mate/​breed/​reproduce/​feed (on something)

examples.x: a packet of wild flower seeds
sesame seeds
Sow the seeds outdoors in spring.
Plant the seeds 10cm apart.
These vegetables can be grown from seed.
seed potatoes (= used for planting)

senses.definition: the small hard seed that is found in some types of fruit
the beginning of a feeling or development that continues to grow

examples.x: the seeds of rebellion
This planted the seeds of doubt in my mind.
He argued that capitalism contained the seeds of its own destruction.

senses.definition: one of the best players in a competition. The seeds are given a position in a list to try and make sure that they do not play each other in the early parts of the competition.

examples.x: The top seed won comfortably.
the number one seed
She was the top seed at the US Open this year.

senses.definition: semen
all the people who are the children, grandchildren, etc. of one man
an area of soil which has been specially prepared for planting seeds in
a place or situation in which something can develop

examples.x: a seedbed for ideas
A secure environment is the seedbed of emotional growth.

senses.definition: a garden tool like a very large pair of scissors, used for cutting bushes and hedges shear

examples.x: a pair of garden shears

senses.definition: a small simple building, usually built of wood or metal, used for keeping things in

examples.x: a bicycle shed
a garden shed
a tool shed

senses.definition: a large industrial building, used for working in or keeping equipment

examples.x: an engine shed

senses.definition: a building with open sides where the wool is cut off sheep (= they are sheared) or where cows are milked
a tool like a spade with a long handle and a broad metal part with curved edges, used for moving earth, snow, sand, etc.

examples.x: workmen with picks and shovels
The children took their pails and shovels to the beach.

senses.definition: the part of a large machine or vehicle that digs or moves earth
to lift and move earth, stones, coal, etc. with a shovel Shovel

examples.x: A gang of workmen were shovelling rubble onto a truck.
They went out in freezing conditions to shovel snow.
to shovel the sidewalk/driveway (= to remove snow)
He sat at the table, shovelling food into his mouth.

senses.definition: a large plant that is smaller than a tree and that has several stems of wood coming from the ground scrub

examples.x: evergreen shrubs
shrub roses

senses.definition: an area planted with shrubs
a small, soft creature, like a snail without a shell, that moves very slowly and often eats garden plants
a small amount of a strong alcoholic drink

examples.x: He took another slug of whisky.

senses.definition: a bullet
a piece of metal like a coin in shape used to get things from machines, etc., sometimes illegally
a small, soft creature with a hard, round shell on its back, that moves very slowly and often eats garden plants. Some types of snail can be eaten.

examples.x: the war with the slugs and snails in my garden

senses.definition: the top layer of the earth in which plants, trees, etc. grow soil

examples.x: instruments for measuring soil moisture
soil erosion
the study of rocks and soils
sandy/fertile soil
rich/poor/dry/wet soil
acid/alkaline soil
clay soil
moisture in the soil
She dug the compost into the soil.

senses.definition: a country; an area of land

examples.x: It was the first time I had set foot on African soil.
protests over the siting of nuclear weapons on British soil
He was the first Canadian to win on home/native soil (= in Canada).

senses.definition: to plant or spread seeds in or on the ground sew

examples.x: Sow the seeds in rows.
Sow the seeds quite thinly.
Water well after sowing.
Sow rows of lettuces between other vegetables.
The fields around had been sown with wheat.
We’ve sown that field with wheat.

senses.definition: to introduce or spread feelings or ideas, especially ones that cause trouble

examples.x: to sow doubt in somebody’s mind
to sow confusion

senses.definition: a garden tool with a broad metal part and a long handle, used for digging

examples.x: Turn the soil over with a spade.
The children took their buckets and spades to the beach.

senses.definition: one of the four suits (= sets) in a pack of cards. The cards have a black design with shapes like pointed leaves with short stems.

examples.x: the five/queen/ace of spades

senses.definition: one card from the suit called spades

examples.x: You must play a spade if you have one.

senses.definition: a device with holes in that is used to spray water in drops onto plants, soil or grass
a device inside a building that sprays out water if it detects a rise in temperature because of a fire
an electric garden tool held in the hands and used for cutting grass that is difficult to cut with a larger machine string
a small building in a garden for sitting in in good weather
a house that somebody lives in only during the summer

a device used outdoors, especially in the past, for telling the time when the sun is shining. A pointed piece of metal throws a shadow on a flat surface that is marked with the hours like a clock, and the shadow moves around as the sun moves across the sky.
a chair with a long seat that supports your legs, used for sitting or lying on in the sun
a light umbrella or other object such as an awning, that is used to protect people from hot sun

examples.x: a child’s buggy fitted with a sunshade

senses.definition: a pair of dark glasses that you wear to protect your eyes from bright light from the sun, especially ones that fix on to your ordinary glasses
an area of water that has been created for people to swim in

examples.x: an indoor/outdoor swimming pool
a heated swimming pool
an open-air swimming pool

senses.definition: the building that contains a public swimming pool

examples.x: She trained five times a week at her local swimming pool.

senses.definition: a swinging movement or rhythm

examples.x: He took a wild swing at the ball.
the swing of her hips

senses.definition: a change from one opinion or situation to another; the amount by which something changes

examples.x: Voting showed a 10 per cent swing to Labour.
There are indications of a swing towards nuclear power.

senses.definition: a seat for swinging on, hung from above on ropes or chains

examples.x: The kids were playing on the swings.
Her dad pushed her on the swing.

senses.definition: the swinging movement you make with your arms and body when you hit the ball in the game of golf

examples.x: I need to work on my swing.

senses.definition: a type of jazz with a smooth rhythm, played especially by big dance bands in the 1930s
a quick journey, especially one made by a politician, in which somebody visits several different places in a short time

examples.x: a three-day campaign swing through California

senses.definition: a continuous row of similar houses that are joined together in one block

examples.x: 12 Albert Terrace

senses.definition: a flat, hard area, especially outside a house or restaurant, where you can sit, eat and enjoy the sun

examples.x: Close to the villa is a big pool with a sun terrace around it.
The view from the roof terrace is spectacular.
All rooms have a balcony or terrace.

senses.definition: the wide steps where people can stand to watch the game
one of a series of flat areas of ground that are cut into the side of a hill like steps so that crops can be grown there

examples.x: The villagers had dug terraces in the hillside.

senses.definition: to take an organ, skin, etc. from one person, animal, part of the body, etc. and put it into or onto another

examples.x: Surgeons have successfully transplanted a liver into a four-year-old boy.
Patients often reject transplanted organs.
Organs are transplanted from donors into patients who need them.

senses.definition: to move a growing plant and plant it somewhere else

examples.x: The Dutch successfully transplanted trees to the East Indies.

senses.definition: to move somebody/something to a different place or environment

examples.x: Japanese production methods have been transplanted into some British factories.

senses.definition: a structure built in the branches of a tree, usually for children to play on
a light frame made of long, narrow pieces of wood that cross each other, used to support climbing plants
to make something neater, smaller, better, etc., by cutting parts from it

to trim a hedge (back)

a neatly-trimmed beard

senses.definition: to cut away unnecessary parts from something

Trim away the lower leaves.

senses.definition: to decorate something, especially around its edges

examples.x: gloves trimmed with fur

senses.definition: a small garden tool with a curved metal part for lifting plants and digging holes
a small tool with a flat metal part, used in building for spreading cement or plaster
a large round container without a lid (= cover), used for washing clothes in, growing plants in, etc.

examples.x: There were tubs of flowers on the balcony.

senses.definition: a small, wide plastic or paper container with a lid (= cover), used for food, etc.

examples.x: a tub of margarine
an empty margarine tub

senses.definition: a bathtub (= a large, long container that you put water in and then get into to wash your whole body)

examples.x: They found her lying in the tub.

senses.definition: a piece of thin rope or wire, attached to posts, that you hang clothes on to dry outside after you have washed them
to pour water on plants, etc.

examples.x: to water the plants/garden

senses.definition: to become full of tears

examples.x: The smoke made my eyes water.

senses.definition: to produce saliva

examples.x: The smells from the kitchen made our mouths water.

senses.definition: to give water to an animal to drink

examples.x: to water the horses
After a tour of the grounds, the guests were fed and watered.

senses.definition: to provide an area of land with water

examples.x: The valley is watered by a stream.

senses.definition: to add water to an alcoholic drink

examples.x: watered wine

senses.definition: a large barrel for collecting rain as it flows off a roof
an artificial area of water, or structure with water flowing through it, which is intended to make a garden more attractive and interesting
a metal or plastic container with a handle and a long spout, used for pouring water on plants
a wild plant growing where it is not wanted, especially among crops or garden plants

examples.x: The yard was overgrown with weeds.

senses.definition: any wild plant without flowers that grows in water and forms a green floating mass
tobacco or cigarettes

examples.x: I wish I could give up the weed (= stop smoking).

senses.definition: the drug cannabis
a person with a weak character or body

examples.x: Don’t be such a weed!

senses.definition: to take out weeds from the ground

examples.x: I've been weeding the flower beds.

senses.definition: a large open container with a wheel and two handles that you use outside to carry things

examples.x: She took the chest home in a wheelbarrow.

senses.definition: a row of trees, a fence, etc. that provides protection from the wind
a long, narrow box outside a window, in which plants are grown

examples.x: floral displays such as window boxes and hanging baskets

senses.definition: a piece of land next to or around your house where you can grow flowers, fruit, vegetables, etc., usually with a lawn (= an area of grass) gardens

examples.x: They have a gorgeous old oak tree in their front yard.
My next-door neighbor was watering her yard.

senses.definition: an area outside a building, usually with a hard surface and a surrounding wall

examples.x: The prisoners were made to line up in the prison yard.
The children were playing in the yard at the front of the school.

senses.definition: an area of land used for a special purpose or business factory

examples.x: a boat yard

senses.definition: a unit for measuring length, equal to 3 feet (36 inches) or 0.9144 of a metre

examples.x: They still live within yards of each other.

senses.definition: a long piece of wood fastened to a mast that supports a sail on a boat or ship
